Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: "Instead, the earnings went down, stock more than doubled" Because the market liked the cause of the earnings difference: accelerated capex for extraordinary expansion. Too bad shorts do not understand these dynamics. Wouldn't they just be better off avoiding shorting stocks they don't understand?

Topic.Title: Internet Groceries have mostly flopped

Message.Msg: "Do you really trust some kid in a "fullfilment center" to pick out your lettuce, avocados and steaks?" Yeah, because you can probably send it back or get a refund if you don't like it and the kid will probably be fired if keeps doing that. Don't kids also pick the lettuce, avocados and other stuff in the back kitchens of MacDonald's where most Amazon shorts have been forced to feed due to their recent heavy losses, or even at finer establishments?

Topic.Title: 140 Billion for a company that has an EPS of -0.19

Message.Msg: Bought small number of 305 July 20th Puts Friday at the close. If I have to I will take a loss on Monday and wait for a better entry point. My Opinions: AMZN is a great company with a stock price that is way ahead of it's future earnings / cash flow prospects. Look what recently happened to AAPL. There is no arguing that the longs have been in control however stocks like AAPL had a lot more going for them before it took big hits. The desparation of shorts continues to rise and so does the overconfidence of longs. Who will win in the short-term is anyone's guess. Technically, AMZN is still incredibly strong however with an RSI at nosebleed levels and up ten days in row it triggered my purchase of Puts .

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: How much is capitalized of the accelerated capex vs expensed. Makes a big difference as earnings should be going up into balance sheet captialziation where you amortize/depreciate the spending over time.

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: Probably explains why they had to get bonds issued in December. "Reinvested" profits didn't cover spending.

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: Very interesting, I'd noticed it but never linked a pattern together as you have. What I find scary about owning this stock at these levels is that a good case could be made that it was fairly (or even richly) valued at $207, not $307. It's a bit like NFLX, and there's a little too much voodoo in the valuation for me.

Topic.Title: 140 Billion for a company that has an EPS of -0.19

Message.Msg: Yes, since they used a lot of that capex build distibution centers much closer to consumers and to the extent they can now use their own trucks for deliveries cutting out middle men like UPS and FDX. "In 2011, Amazon changed its fulfillment strategy and began building new distribution warehouses closer to large, heavily populated areas such as Los Angeles and San Francisco. In the first quarter of 2013, Amazon's shipping costs were 4.7 percent of revenue, down from 5.1 percent a year earlier. "For a company the size of Amazon, that's a pretty big deal," said R.J. Hottovy, an equity analyst at Morningstar. "That could be potentially very disruptive to UPS and FedEx," he added."

Topic.Title: 140 Billion for a company that has an EPS of -0.19

Message.Msg: Other retailers have not done as much as Amazon in reducing non-fuel price related shipping cost (using their own trucks, building centers closer to consumers). Interest rates? I guess they weight that risk against doing nothing and paying higher shipping expenses instead to UPS, FDX and over further distances like out of state distribution centers.

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: Depends on the discretionary choice of whether or not Amazon aggressively (rapidly) amortize them or not. Most shorts tend to only invest in Old World stocks like Walmart and so they assume Amazon amortizes at similar rates as a brick and mortar operation. They never bother to check this.

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: And look how much the market applauded the move by Amazon in ceasing the investment opportunity. How was it anything but a great idea, and how was it anything but a horrible, horrible nightmare if you were short?

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: You misunderstand the short-term impact of expansion. Capex simply indicates some of the extent of an expansion which may have greater or lesser impact on the the Statement of Operations depending on rates of amortization. Short-term what happens is that you have lots of new centers operating at their lowest capacity with staff that are being trained and are also not operating optimally yet. As with previous cycles as optimization takes place over time returns become parabolic indeed such is in the several years subsequent to the last investment phase.

Topic.Title: 140 Billion for a company that has an EPS of -0.19

Message.Msg: Interesting, AMZN is now adding on the hat of being a "shipping company" as well as a retailor, cloud computing, digital.media creator/deliverer etc.: DO have any timeframe in your head when the top line scale will start again to the bottom line with all this? I thought $64 billion might do it but not yet. Perhaps as long as the market merely keeps rewarding spending inititiatives as shown by driving the market cap higher and higher along with Bernankes' $85 billion a month, there will never be a need for profits anytime soon. Certainly WS and investors see the scale story still intact somewhere ahead to drop profits the botttoml line. A $10 earnings/shr drop,whenever it comes, puts AMZN at almost a 31 multiple today on that level. And that's almost a four bagger to record earnings in history. So the earnings when they come, are gonna be a sigth to see ahead. There's never been more confidence by the market and WS that's it's a slam dunk. somewhere ahead. You've been correct all along on the market assumptions of it all.. more intact than ever:congrats.

Message.Msg: "Technology and content costs are expensed as incurred" This was accounted for the largest acceleration in all of the expense line items. And no, if you can read English you will note that it does not say "over time", it says "as incurred."

Topic.Title: AMZN is twice market cap of GS,

Message.Msg: Except what they did with shipping reduced their expenses. More than physical? How is relying on UPS's or FDX's physical assets any different? You just pay more to a middle man. I can see you do not have much of a head for business. You would rather pay more to a third party than pay less by foregoing them in order to claim you aren't reliant on your own physical assets.

Topic.Title: I am inventing the AMZN Rule

Message.Msg: I never had to worry about that. At $150 shorts told me it was too high but it wasn't and now it has doubled. I've done very well by reversing the short's "logic", so I guess that means until they start saying to buy I should stay long. The Fed has always printed money and will continue doing so until long after you are dead. Betting on them this changing is not a good way to prevent your getting your next margin call on an Amazon short.

Message.Title: crack head optionz
Message.Msg: I did some analysis on the optionz that expire next friday. Here's what I got: There are a total of 40k call contracts and 30k are in the money. There are a total of 32k put contracts and 545 are in the money. If amzn closes at 307.55 next week, call contracts will payout 88.6 million... put contracts will payout 700k. Max Pain is at 280... calls would pay out 25 million and puts would payout at 13.3 million. If the optionz writers have any influence over the stock price, its hard to see amzn going up next week.

Topic.Title: Insider Sales
Insider Sales

Message.Msg: " didn't see even one share they bought from the market yet." huh? When have you ever seen insider buying in AMZN stock? Don't hold your breath until you do. It won't happens. Nor does the insiders selling mean anything bad over the years: It's no indication at all to stock performance. In fact, more power to the insiders to take advantage of it, as someone keeps moving the stock higher and higher. We shold be so lucky to have that type of backing merely on their spending/buildout.

Topic.Title: Insider Sales

Message.Msg: party_bistro, i take it you're long. i, on the other hand am short, and last week really hurt. i'm not pointing out insider sales to bolster the argument that amzn is over-valued. the fundamentals do that. as a short, i'm actually a bit concerned to see insider sales decelerate. by historical standards, insider sales are very small. finally, i agree with you, insider sales in and of themselves have little meaning for a company that grants so many options. if i worked at a company that i thought had good prospects, i'd sell my options to diversify.

Topic.Title: crack head optionz

Topic.Title: What Happened To Sybil/Trannyboy Waiting Till 245 To Post Again??????
crack head optionz

Message.Msg: Good observation, and certainly a possible reason for some downward pressure. However, here's another way to look at look at all those calls: if a large number of them are naked sales, then those sellers will have to buy stock in the open market to be able to deliver on the calls. This scenario would provide some upward pressure on the stock until they have enough stock to deliver. A simplistic bit of info in a complex market with many other factors at work. Personally NP, got stopped out of last short.

Topic.Title: crack head optionz

Message.Msg: It would be nice to know who's writing all of those call contracts. Its hard for me to believe that they are mostly written by naked retail investors. It seems more likely that institutions are writing these contracts. Who knows?

Topic.Title: crack head optionz

Message.Msg: Traders are more sophisticated than that, it's unlikely that traders would write naked calls against AMZN. That's just asking for it...would you really take a chance on being assigned a short position with a stock as hot as AMZN. Much more likely they did what I did, they purchased calls out of the money and AMZN kept on moving up during the last month. Now, all of a sudden their calls are in the money. Looking at the coming week, it looks like GOOG will run-up to earnings on Thursday and possibly carry AMZN and the sector with them. So, I'll probably sell my calls during the early part of the week.
